revision.comment: /* soy sauce listed in a 'gluten-free' recipe? */ new section
revision.text:
This article needs work and appears to be wrong. What is the origin of this recipe? This is not cashew chicken as served in Springfield, Missouri where it originated. Cashews are a garnish added at the very end along with green onions. There are no vegetables in cashew chicken, ''that'' is a variation. The recipe should be (as reasonably close) as the one first used at Leong's Tea House in Springfield where the dish was first invented. Using vegetables and other methods are the variations. I lived in Springfield, Missouri all my life and never ate this at a Chinese restaurant.[[User:Rt66lt|Rt66lt]] 18:09, 3 February 2006 (UTC)
:This was already neatly described in the "variations" section. Leong might know his audience, but damn that's not normal cashew chicken. See [[Cookbook:Leong's Cashew Chicken]] for the recipe. (would Midwestern Cashew Chicken be a better name?) [[User:AlbertCahalan|AlbertCahalan]] 05:18, 14 April 2006 (UTC)
I have lived in Springfield, MO for five years now. Before that I lived in San Francisco (they have a few good Chinese restaurants there), New York City (as well), and Boston. The cashew chicken served here in the so-called "Birthplace of Cashew Chicken" is nothing more than fried chicken with brown gravy, and cashews sprinkled on top. Who let the hillbilly into the kitchen?
== soy sauce listed in a 'gluten-free' recipe? ==
I'm trying to find a gluten-free recipe, and happy to have this resource, but lo and behold, I see that soy sauce is listed here without any caveat or gluten warnings, yet wheat (i.e., gluten) appears to be a primary ingredient in soy sauce. This makes me question other recipes on the gluten free list...bummer!

Hi everyone,
My name is Ralfe Poisson. I am currently a student in South Africa. I am aiming to qualify as a Forensic Psychologist, however I have many areas of interest. I enjoy Computer related topics, and I actually work part time as a programmer. I also am in to music, I play the Piano and Violin semi-proffesionally. I also sing and play the guitar, recorder, drum kit and djembe (a traditionaly African drum). I am greatly interested in all things Psychological, from Neuropsychology to Graphology. I am passionate about OpenSource and Free Learning, and am very activly involved in OpenSource Software development and promotion.
You can email me at ralfepoisson@gmail.com

page.title: Taxation in the United Kingdom/Corporation tax/Who pays corporation tax?

revision.text:
'''Corporation tax is payable by:'''
#[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Corporation tax/Definitions/Residency|UK resident]] [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Company|companies]] on its worldwide [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Profits|profits]]<ref>[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 6 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 6 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988]]</ref><ref>[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 8 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 8 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988]]</ref> #Non-UK resident companies that carry on a trade in the United Kingdom through a [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Corporation tax/Permanent establishment|permanent establishment]] on its [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Permanent establishment/Profits|profits attributable to the permanent establishment]]<ref>[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 11 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 11 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988]]</ref>
"Company" here means any body corporate or unincorporated association but does not include a partnership, a local authority or a [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Local authority association|local authority association]] <ref>[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 832 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 832 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988]]</ref>
That doesn't mean that overseas companies that are not trading in the United Kingdom through a permanent establishment are exempt from all tax as they may still be liable to income tax, typically on UK rental income.
:''Next page: [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Corporation tax/Residents and non-residents|Residents and non-residents]]''
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Taxation in the United Kingdom]]

'''General Apraxia'''
Apraxia is the partial or complete loss of one's ability to perform deliberate movements. This results from cortical lesions where there is no paralysis or loss of sensory functioning.
'''Akinetic Apraxia'''
Apraxia characterized by the inability to perform spontaneous movements.
'''Amnesic Apraxia'''
Also known as amnestic apraxia, is apraxia which is characterised by an inability to carry out sequence(s) of movement upon request. Generally, the cause for this is deteriorated memory.
'''Buccofacial Apraxia'''
Apraxia characterised by an inability to carry out voluntary movements involving the face, mouth and tongue.
'''Constructional Apraxia'''
Apraxia characterised by a deficit in the ability to draw or assemble objects. This form of apraxia is caused by lesions in the right hemisphere, usually on the right parietal lobe.
'''Ideational Apraxia'''
Apraxia characterised by the improper use of objects caused by an inability to identify them correctly or to conceptualize their appropriate functions.
'''Ideokinetic Apraxia'''
Apraxia which is characterised by an inability to carry out a series of ordered movements. The patient is usually able to carry out individual orders, but is confused by a sequence of orders.
'''Ideomotor Apraxia'''
Apraxia characterised by the inability to execute a single, complex movement properly. The patient performs inappropriate movements in the course of action.
'''Left Parietal Apraxia'''
This is apraxia caused by damage to the posterior lobe of the left hemisphere.'
'''Motor Apraxia'''
Apraxia involving the inability to carry out planned acts.
'''Ocular Apraxia'''
Apraxia characterised by an inability to maintain fixation. With Ocular Apraxia, the patient's eyes wander back and forth between objects.
'''References''' Reber, A.S; Reber, E. "The Penguin Dictionary of Psychology", 3rd Edition. 2001.
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

'''Definition of Generalized Agnosia'''
A defect in recognition, where a patient can generally sense objects and forms, but is unable to consciously recognize and interpret the meaning of the sensory input.
'''Apperceptive Agnosia'''
Agnosia characterised by recognition failure caused by impairment in visual perception. Patients are unable to recognize objects despite having normal acuity.
'''Associative Agnosia'''
A visual Agnosia characterised by the lack of meaning associated with percepts despite the patient being able to normally percieve an object and draw it.
'''Auditory Agnosia'''
Agnosia characterised by the inability to recognize sounds despite the patient having normal auditory functioning. Auditory Agnosia is typically associated with nonspeech sounds. When agnosia involves speech, it is referred to as "pure word deafness"
'''Ideational Agnosia'''
Agnosia characterised by faulty recognition and interpretation of symbols.
'''Landmark Agnosia'''
Agnosia characterized by the inability to recognize stable objects in the environment. Patients can typically describe them in detail, but are unable to describe or recognize them.
'''Tactile Agnosia'''
Agnosia characterized by the inability to recognize and interpret objects by touch.
'''Visual Agnosia'''
Agnosia characterized by the inability to recognize and interpret objects in the visual field. Visual Agnosia may also sometimes be referred to as "Optic Agnosia".
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

== Definition == Dementia is the loss of intellectual capacity to the extent that normal social and occupational functions can no longer be carried out.
== Alzheimer's Disease == Alzheimer's disease is a progressive form of dementia characterized by the grandual deterioration of intellectual abilities such as memory, judgement, capacity for abstract thought, and other higher-level cognitive functions.
The onset of presenile Alzheimer's disease is usually after the age of 40 and consists of three main phases. The first phase lasts for 2 to 3 years, and is characterized by failing memory, muddled inefficiency over mundane tasks as well as spatial disorientation. Mood disorders are prominent and take the form of perplexity, agitation and restless hyperactivity. In the second phase, there is greater intellectual and personality deterioration. Focal symptoms also appear. In the third (or terminal) stage, there is extreme apathetic dementia in which the patient becomes bedridden. Neurological disabilities may develop, such as spastic hemiparesis (hemispheric paralysis) or severe striatal rigidity (irregular streaks or patches of nerve cell loss in the cerebral cortex) and tremor.
Histologically, there is degeneratoin and loss of nerve cells which affects the outer three cortical layers and the thalamus as well as secondary glial proliferatoin (the rapid growth of the plial cells which perform support tasks such as production of the myelin sheath and nutritional support). Senile plaques and neurofibrallary tangles are characteristic of Alzheimer's disease and the neurofibrillary tangles occur in grey matter, particularly in the hippocampus and amygdala. The senile plaque lie within the nerve cells and often fill the entire cell body, and may have no core and appear to consist on ly of granular or filamentous fragments. Cortical atrophy (the wasting away of the cortex) is also present and tends to affect the frontal and temporal lobes. The white matter shows axonal degeneration, hyperplasia (the increase in organ size caused by an abnormal increase in number of cells) of astrocytes as well as fibrous gliosis (the replacement of neuron cells by glia cells). Other characteristic features include shrinking of the brain, flattening of the gyri, widening of the sulci and enlarging of the ventricles.
The walls of intracerebral arteries tend to thicken with advancing age. The collagen in the outer layers become more prominent which causes the wall and surrounding tissue to die and, in most cases, disintegrate. There is an interference of cerebral cirulation which is caused by blockage of the common carotid, inner carotid and venebral arteries in the neck and bony channels of the skull. With regards neuro-chemistry, there are also deficiencies in neurotransmitters such as acetylcholine, noradrenaline, serotonin and somatostatin.
there seem to be certain general triggers for Alzheirmer's diseas such as minimal brain damage from head injury, infection and surgery. However, the illness is usually already in existence, and these "triggers" or precipitants have merely revealed the problem.
As so far as treatment is concerned, there is no cure. However, cutting edge research in stem cell development is showing promising results for counteracting the degenerative effects of Alzheimer's Disease.
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]] [[Category:Alzheimer's disease]] [[Category:Dementia]]

page.title: Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 6 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988

revision.text:
This section sets out the general rubric of the charge to corporation tax.
Subsection (1) raises the charge on profits of companies. Profits are defined in Subsection (5), [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Company|company]] is defined in [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 832 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 832 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988 (ICTA)]]. This definition includes overseas companies, and it is left to [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 11 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 11 of ICTA]] to restrict the scope of the charge for overseas entities.
Tax is charged, and the [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Corporation Tax Acts|Corporation Tax Acts]] apply for any [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Financial year|Financial year]] for which Parliament charges corporation tax. The wording is formulated in this way because corporation tax, like income tax, is still a temporary tax which must be imposed annually, although in practice it is inconceivable that a Parliament will fail to levy the tax.
Subsection (2) provides that where a company is [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Residency|UK resident]] (and so within the full charge), or overseas resident but not scoped out of the charge to corporation tax by [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 11 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 11 of ICTA]], the [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definition/Income Tax Acts|Income Tax Acts]] (and therefore the charge to income tax) do not apply.
Subsection (3) removes any charge to capital gains tax on gains on which it is charged to corporation tax or would be so chargeable but for an exemption from corporation tax.
Subsection (4) defines "profits" and widens the meaning of "trade" for the purposes of Sections 7 to 12, 114, 115 (subject to 115(7)) and 248, and Part VIII, Chapter IV of Part X, and Part XI, except where the context requires otherwise. '''[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Profits|Profits]]''' are defined as [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Income|income]] and [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Chargeable gains|chargeable gains]]. '''Trade''' is taken to include '''vocation''', and to include an office or employment.
Subsection (4A) extends the meaning of '''[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Profession|profession]]''' to include vocation in Sections 74(1), 79(1), 79A(1), 79B(1), 83A(1), 84(1), 86(1), 86A(2)(a), 87(1), (2) and (4), 88, 89, 90(1) and (3), 94(1), 100(2)(b), 101, 102, 401(1), 491(10), 577(7)(b), 579(2), 588(3), 589A(8) and 817(2), and in paragraph 5(11) of Schedule 30.
Subsection (5) notes that Part VIII contains general provisions relating to the taxation of profits of companies. [[Category:Taxation in the United Kingdom]]

The meaning of the word '''Profession''' is extended by [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 6 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 6(4) of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988]] to include vocation in Sections 74(1), 79(1), 79A(1), 79B(1), 83A(1), 84(1), 86(1), 86A(2)(a), 87(1), (2) and (4), 88, 89, 90(1) and (3), 94(1), 100(2)(b), 101, 102, 401(1), 491(10), 577(7)(b), 579(2), 588(3), 589A(8) and 817(2) of ICTA and in paragraph 5(11) of Schedule 30 to ICTA.
[[Category:Taxation in the United Kingdom]]

page.title: Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 7 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988

revision.text:
Subsection (1) provides that no payment made by a [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Residency|UK resident]] [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/company|company]] shall be treated as income tax, and also that a requirement to withhold income tax imposed by the [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Income Tax Acts|Income Tax Acts]] stands notwithstanding that the company is not within the charge to income tax itself.
Subsection (2) provides that subject to provision for the contrary, a UK resident company that has received a payment net of withheld income tax may set that income tax off against its corporation tax liability of the [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/accounting period|accounting period]] in which the receipt is brought into the corporation tax charge, or would have been brought into the corporation tax charge but for an exemption from corporation tax.
Subsection (3) disapplies subsection (2) for a payment of loan interest to which [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 369 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 369 of ICTA]] applies. Section 369 deals with mortgage relief at source. As mortgage relief at source no longer applies, this subsection no longer has any practical effect.
Subsection (4) expands, for the purposes of this section, the references to payments received by a company to include references to payments received by another person on behalf of or in trust for the company. It also excludes money received by a company on behalf of or in trust for another person.
[[Category:Taxation in the United Kingdom]]

[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 6 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 6(4) of ICTA]] defines '''profits''' for the purposes of Sections 7 to 12, 114, 115 (subject to 115(7)) and 248, and Part VIII, Chapter IV of Part X, and Part XI of ICTA except where the context requires otherwise as:
*[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Income|income]] and [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Chargeable gains|chargeable gains]].
[[Category:Taxation in the United Kingdom]]

page.title: Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 8 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988

revision.comment: [[Hoy hoy!!]] moved to [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 8 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988]]
revision.text:
Subsection (1) provides that, subject to an explicit exception in the [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Corporation Tax Acts|Corporation Tax Acts]], [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Company|companies]] are taxed on their worldwide profits.
Subsection (2) makes it clear that a company is taxable on all profits accruing to its benefits, including profits of trusts and partnerships, if it would be taxed on them if it received the profits direct. Except in the case where the company is being wound up (where it receives profits for the benefit of its creditors or members, as appropriate), it is not taxed on profits it receives in a fiduciary capacity. This subsection (which is well supported by case law) effectively states that for tax purposes you look at beneficial, not legal, ownership of profits.
Subsection (3) provides that corporation tax is computed and chargeable by reference to [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Accounting period|accounting periods]], although tax is charged by reference to [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Financial year|financial years]]. The profits of accounting periods are apportioned between the financial years in which the accounting period falls. [[Category:Taxation in the United Kingdom]]

page.title: Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 9 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988

revision.comment: [[Hey hey!!]] moved to [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 9 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988]]
revision.text:
Subsection (1) provides that corporation tax is charged under income tax principles, unless there is a provision to the contrary, and for these purposes the corporation tax term "[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Accounting period|accounting period]]" is taken to be the period of reference rather than the income tax term "[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Year of assessment|Year of assessment]]". This provision derives from when corporation tax was first introduced in 1965 (prior to which companies were charged to income tax). Since 2003, various parts of the [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Income Tax Acts|Income Tax Acts]] have been rewritten so that the same provisions no longer apply for both income tax and corporation tax. This process is not yet complete, but by the end of the decade, corporation tax should be a completely stand-alone tax, no longer relying on income tax provisions for its base.
Subsection (2) makes it clear what income tax law applies for each accounting period, and also that provisions relating specifically to individuals do not apply to persons within the charge to corporation tax.
Subsection (2A) provides that corporation tax on income is not charged under the Income Tax (Trading and Other Income) Act 2005 (ITTOIA). Subsection (2B) goes on to provide that instead income is chargeable under [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 15 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Schedule A]] and [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 18 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Schedule D]] and the Cases of Schedule D. Subsection (2C) also deems Schedules A and D to apply to income tax for the purposes of corporation tax. In essence, these subsections contain transitional provisions that apply whilst corporation tax law is being decoupled from income tax law - once the decoupling is complete, they will no longer be necessary.
Subsection (3) provides that total profits are assessed under and computed under the rules in [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 15 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Schedule A]] and [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 18 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Schedule D]] and also under Parts 2 (employment income), 9 (pension income) and 10 (social security income) of ITEPA (which impose the charge to income) tax plus [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Chargeable gain|chargeable gains]].
Subsection (4) provides that where a provision of the [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Income Tax Acts|Income Tax Acts]] apart from ITTOIA provides for an exemption from income tax, or charges a person to income tax, then unless otherwise provided, there is a similar exemption from or charge to corporation tax.
Subsection (5) makes it clear that although corporation tax and income tax are distinct taxes, the same statutory provision may apply to them. This also allows certain provisions to ensure tax neutrality between persons within the charge to corporation tax and income tax by being a rule for corporation tax as far as the former is concerned, and a rule for income tax as far as the latter is concerned. A charge to corporation tax (or income tax) is a charge to the other, and an exemption from corporation tax (or income tax) is an exemption to the other, unless expressed explicitly to the contrary.
Subsection (6) states that the [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Income Tax Acts|Income Tax Acts]] referred to in the section are to be taken as excluding Section 1 to 5, Part VII or Sections 348 to 350 of ICTA, and notes that the above rules do not refer to which period income are taxed in, except to the extent that this results from apportioning income of the whole period to different parts of a period. [[Category:Taxation in the United Kingdom]]

It seems to be a great text. I see questions as section heads, as we have it in the Klexikon, but that does not seem to be universal in the English Wikibooks Wikijunior project? Sometimes I wondered about some terms. For example, I don't know what the Morrison formation is, I would have to look that up. Maybe US American children know the term? page.title: When It Hits the Fan/Specific Calamities/Historical events

revision.comment: /* 1910s */ corrected, reformatted and imported the content regarding the subject from [[US History/Advancements]]
revision.text:
=== Events sorted chronologically === This section of the book lists disastrous events until the last century. We have intentionally not listed more recent events because they may be still under active dispute, badly attributed, too painful and in general still open to distinct interpretation and requiring further analysis.
==== 20th century ====
===== 1980s ===== *[[w:Armero tragedy|1985 Nevado del Ruiz Lahar disaster]] - The 'Volcán del Ruiz', had been for more than a century a dormant giant, which travelers in the Bogotá-Cali flights had the pleasure to observe, covered with a large snow cap.
:With 5,389 m (17,780 ft), Nevado del Ruiz is the highest of the Colombian volcanoes in the Central Range of the Colombian Andes.
:Although this volcano had caused lahars in 1595 and 1845, causing hundreds of deaths, the rich valley of [[w:Armero|Armero]] under the peak, was excellent agricultural land. The town of Armero grew for more than a century, without anyone remembering the old disasters.
:Late in 1984, geologists began to notice small earthquakes and steam eruptions in the volcano. Although a network of monitoring devices was setup on the summit of the volcano, nothing would predict the terrible events that followed a year later.
:In November 1985 the smoke from the summit of Nevado del Ruiz, was plainly visible, but both authorities and scientists alike didn't believe these were the preliminaries of a plynian pyroclastic eruption.
:Despite the warnings local authorities in Armero, and state officials keep saying no eruption would follow, although a risk map was in place.
:On the night of November 13, 1985, at around 3:00 pm there was an explosion and ashes fell over the region, but even then local authorities and priests in Armero asked the people to remain calm in their houses. However at 9:30 pm. the volcano, covered with storm clouds, erupted with rock ejection and pyroclastic discharges which melted the snow cap. Melted water and pyroclastic ashes and rocks mixed and produced a series of lahars, mud and rock slides along the rivers.
:Just half an hour short of midnight on November 13, 1985 a massive Lahar caused by the eruption of the volcano, ran down the Lagunillas river, in central Colombia, and jumped in a 200 high wave of rocks, mud and debris over the town of Armero, 28,000 inhabitants. In the next 10 minutes close to 80% of Armero was destroyed. The death toll of both the lahar that hit Armero and other lahars was estimated at 21,000 deaths.
===== 1930s ===== *[[w:Holodomor|1932 - Ukraine - Black Famine]] - A Man-Made Famine raged through Ukraine, the ethnic-Ukrainian region of northern Caucasus, and the lower Volga River region in 1932-33. Between 7 to 10 million people, mainly Ukrainians, starved to death.
:Planned by Soviet leader Joseph Stalin, the main goal of this artificial famine was to break the spirit of the Ukrainian peasant farmer and to force them into collectivization. In 1932, the Soviets increased the grain procurement quota for Ukraine by 44%. Soviet law was quite clear - no grain could be given to feed the peasants until the quota was met, aware that this extraordinary high quota would result in a grain shortage leaving Ukrainian peasant unable to feed themselves.
:When some peasants attempted to hide grain from the Soviet Government, Communist party officials with the aid of military troops and NKVD secret police units moved into the area. To insure Ukrainian peasants could not travel in search of food, an internal passport system was implemented to restrict movements.
:While Ukrainians were starving, Ukrainian grain was collected and stored in grain elevators that were guarded by military units & NKVD secret police units. *[[/Great Depression/]]
===== 1910s ===== *[[w:Great Lakes Storm of 1913|1913 - Great Lakes, USA & Canada - Great Lakes storm]][[Image:Titanic-New York Herald front page.jpeg|thumb]] *1912 - Atlantic Ocean - Sinking of the R.M.S. Titanic a Olympic-class passenger liner owned by the White Star Line and built at the Harland and Wolff shipyard. On the night of 14 April 1912, during her maiden voyage, Titanic struck an iceberg at a spot around four hundred miles south of Newfoundland, and sank two hours and forty minutes later in early 15 April 1912. There was no long gash in the ship as expected from the iceberg collision but many tiny gashes that led to the flood of the water. Her fireman compared the sound of the impact to "the tearing of calico, nothing more." However, the collision was fatal and the icy water soon poured through the ship. It became obvious that many would not find safety in a lifeboat. Each passenger was issued a life jacket but life expectancy would be short when exposed to water four degrees below freezing. The sinking resulted in the deaths of 1,517 people, ranking it as one of the worst peacetime maritime disasters in history and by far the most infamous. The Titanic used some of the most advanced technology available. It was on of the most luxurious and largest steamship at the time and was popularly believed to be “unsinkable” - indeed, in a 1910 White Star Line brochure advertising the Titanic, claiming that it was "designed to be unsinkable". It was a great shock to many that despite the advanced technology and experienced crew, the Titanic still sank with a great loss of life. The media frenzy about Titanic's famous victims, the legends about what happened on board the ship, the resulting changes to maritime law, and the discovery of the wreck in 1985 by an American and French team, led by Robert Ballard have made Titanic persistently famous in the years since.
===== 1900s ===== [[Image:General slocum burning.jpg|thumbnail|300px|right|Firefighters working to extinguish the General Slocum]] *[[w:PS General Slocum|1904 - New York City, USA - General Slocum disaster]] - The '''''General Slocum''''' was a [[w:steamship|steamship]] launched in [[w:1891|1891]]. It caught fire and burned to the water line in [[w:New York|New York]]'s [[w:East River|East River]] on [[w:June 15|June 15]], [[w:1904|1904]]. Over 1,000 people died in the tragedy, making it New York City's worst loss-of-life disaster until the [[w:September 11, 2001 attacks|September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks]] on the World Trade Center. The Captain, William Van Schaick, and the rest of the crew suffered no fatalities, although the Captain lost sight in one eye due to the fire. There were many acts of heroism among the passengers, witnesses, and emergency personnel. *[[w:1900 Galveston Hurricane|1900 - Texas, USA - Galveston Hurricane]]
==== 19th century ==== *[[w:Krakatoa|1883 - Indonesia - Krakatoa volcano's eruption]]
==== 18th century ==== [[Image:1755 Lisbon earthquake.jpg|thumb|340px|This 1755 copper engraving shows the ruins of Lisbon in flames and a tsunami overwhelming the ships in the harbor.]] *[[w:1755 Lisbon earthquake|1755 Lisbon, Portugal earthquake]] - Took place on November 1, 1755, at 9:20 in the morning. It was one of the most destructive and deadly [[w:earthquakes|earthquakes]] in history, killing well over 70,000 people. The quake was followed by a [[w:tsunami|tsunami]] and fire, resulting in the near total destruction of [[w:Lisbon|Lisbon]].
:The earthquake accentuated political tensions in [[w:Portugal|Portugal]] and profoundly disrupted the country's 18th century colonial ambitions. The event was widely discussed by European Enlightenment [[philosophy|philosophers]], and inspired major developments in [[w:theodicy|theodicy]] and in the philosophy of the [[w:sublime (philosophy)|sublime]]. The first to be studied scientifically for its effects over a large area, the quake signaled the birth of modern [[w:seismology|seismology]]. [[w:Geologists|Geologists]] today estimate the Lisbon earthquake approached magnitude 9 on the Richter scale, with an [[w:epicenter|epicenter]] in the Atlantic Ocean about 200 km west-southwest of [[w:Cape St. Vincent|Cape St. Vincent]].
:The geological causes of this earthquake and the seismic activity in the region continue to be discussed and debated by contemporary scientists. Some geologists have suggested that the earthquake may indicate the early development of an Atlantic subduction zone, and the beginning of the closure of the Atlantic ocean.
==== 17th century ====
==== 16th century ====
==== 15th century ====
==== 14th century ==== *[[/Bubonic Plague/]] The black death occurred in almost all of Europe, killing one third of the population. It was caused by a disease carried by fleas (and spread by rats) and transmitted to humans
==== 1st Century ====
*79 Destruction of Pompeii & Herculaneum by eruption of Mount Vesuvius
{{BookCat}}

revision.text: Hi.

Hola, Shalom! == Welcome! == I hope you found some Poly Science classes. If not perhaps we could start some by playing with some political discussion formats either here locally or at wikireason. (Link on the front page. We could pick some topics or current issues and invite people from a few communities such as kurohin5, slash/dot, and advogato to help discuss it. Hope to see you around. If you get bored or busy, please checkback. I think we are finally nearing some effective initialization. BTW Might run a search on wikibooks or wikpedia regarding specific political topics. Later. [[User:Lazyquasar|Lazyquasar]] 06:12, 2 April 2006 (UTC) P.S. Consider adding your name to the overall participant list[http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Wikiversity:participants] or at specific courses of interest to help others with similar interests find you. == Your account will be renamed ==
Hello, The developer team at Wikimedia is making some changes to how accounts work, as part of our on-going efforts to provide new and better tools for our users like cross-wiki notifications. These changes will mean you have the same account name everywhere. This will let us give you new features that will help you edit and discuss better, and allow more flexible user permissions for tools. One of the side-effects of this is that user accounts will now have to be unique across all 900 Wikimedia wikis. See [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Single User Login finalisation announcement|the announcement]] for more information. Unfortunately, your account clashes with another account also called Wikizach. To make sure that both of you can use all Wikimedia projects in future, we have reserved the name Wikizach~enwikibooks that only you will have. If you like it, you don't have to do anything. If you do not like it, you can [[Special:GlobalRenameRequest|pick out a different name]]. Your account will still work as before, and you will be credited for all your edits made so far, but you will have to use the new account name when you log in. Sorry for the inconvenience. Yours,
[[m:User:Keegan (WMF)|Keegan Peterzell]]
Community Liaison, Wikimedia Foundation

I am a former administrator of [[w:Main page|Wikipedia]] where I had the same username, however I have quit the project, so please leave any messages here.
Previously at Wikibooks I have made major contributions to [[Wikijunior Dinosaurs]]. I am currently looking around looking at various areas where I may help out.

== Writing Software to Play the Ancient Game of Go == {{wikipedia|Computer Go}} [[w:Go (board game)|Go]] is a strategic, two-player game that originated in ancient China thousands of years ago. It is popular throughout East Asia, and is gaining popularity among computer programmers because of its extraordinary complexity. Whereas the top chess-playing computer programs are now better than the top human grand masters, the best Go-playing computer programs currently in existence can be defeated even by amateur Go players.
The rules of Go are simple, but the strategies complex; the sheer number of legal moves at any point in the game make programming an effective opponent a daunting task. This book endeavors to help the novice who is beginning to write software to play the ancient game of Go, as well as to provide a useful resource to those already skilled in the art.
==The Go Community== It is becoming very common for Go players to use the Internet to meet, discuss games, and play one another. Many strong players now regularly [[Computer Go/Playing Go Online|play Go online]]. There is also a growing community of people who write Go software programs, with regular competitions and tournaments between the various Go-playing engines. See [[Computer Go/How Do I Find Other Programs To Play Against?|How Do I Find Other Programs To Play Against?]]
==Where Do I Start?== The best place to start is with the [http://senseis.xmp.net/?RulesOfGoIntroductory rules of Go]. Once you are comfortable with the rules, you may want to [[Computer Go/Playing Go Online|play a few games]] yourself. At that point you can begin with whichever chapter of this book you find most interesting:
* [[/Writing a Go Engine|Writing a Go Engine]]: the innards of a Go-playing program [[Image:75%.svg]] * [[/Writing a GTP Engine|Writing a GTP Engine]]: the protocol that allows to programs to play Go against each other [[File:00%.svg]] * [[/Writing an SGF Parser|Writing an SGF Parser]]: the file format in which Go games are stored [[File:00%.svg]] * [[/Writing a Go GUI|Writing a Go GUI]]: the way humans interact with a Go-related program [[File:00%.svg]]
==Miscellaneous Resources== * [[/Developer Resources|Developer Resources]] * [[/Open source code|Open source code]] * [[/GNU Go|GNU Go]] * [[/Utilities|Utilities]] * [[/Mailing Lists|Mailing Lists]]
{{subjects|Board games|Computer programming}} {{alphabetical|C}} {{status|25%}} __NOTOC__

==Writing a Go Engine== This chapter will walk you through the process of writing a very simple Go Engine capable of recognizing illegal moves and processing the results of moves by removing captured stones. * [[Computer Go/Representing the Board|Representing the Board]] * [[Computer Go/Recognizing Illegal Moves|Recognizing Illegal Moves]] * [[Computer Go/Processing a Move|Processing a Move]] ==Miscellaneous Resources== [http://indessed.com/GoSampleCode.zip Sample Code]
A zip file containing all the sample code for this chapter (written in Java 5). [[Category:Computer Go]]

== Please do not blank pages == I noticed your recent work at [[Modern Greek/Contents]]. Everything seems good, except that while you were merging, you made three pages blank: [[Greek: Introduction]], [[Greek: Alphabet]], and [[Greek: Phonology]]. When you make a blank page, what happens is that there are still links at Wikibooks and the Internet. Some readers will use these links, and instead of finding the [[Modern Greek/Contents]] page where you did all the work, they will find useless blank pages. Thus '''please do not make blank pages''' because they will stop some readers from reading what you worked on! The good news is that ''I was able to fix'' the blank pages by changing them into redirects. Briefly, you can redirect one page to another by replacing the page with one line like this: 
#redirect [[Modern Greek/Contents]]
It helped much that you had typed a "summary" (in the box just above the "Save page" button) each time that you blanked a page, explaining that you were merging. From there, I knew that you were not deleting content, and was able to make the redirects. Thanks for contributing to Wikibooks, and I hope that you continue to work at Wikibooks and provide a "summary" with your edits. --[[User:Kernigh|Kernigh]] 03:25, 4 February 2006 (UTC) == [[:Image:Modern greek song aidoni.ogg]] == You haven't set license of this file. You can see list of licenses at [[WB:ICT]]. You wrote that you copied this file from a website - you should know that we don't allow this unless source releases files under a free license. --[[User:Derbeth|Derbeth]] [[User talk:Derbeth|talk]] 09:43, 16 February 2006 (UTC) == Copying images from Wikipedia == Please don't copy images from Wikipedia. Instead, upload them to Commons - it is as easy as uploading them here and you don't create redundant images. After uploading an image to Commons, remember to mark image on Wikipedia with {{tl1|NowCommons|image at commons}}. --[[User:Derbeth|Derbeth]] [[User talk:Derbeth|talk]] 10:05, 22 February 2006 (UTC) : You don't have to do anything special. Images on Commons are treated as they were here. --[[User:Derbeth|Derbeth]] [[User talk:Derbeth|talk]] 11:18, 25 February 2006 (UTC) == Unused files == Can you take a look at [http://en.wikibooks.org/w/index.php?title=Special:Unusedimages&limit=50&offset=800]? There are some files of yours. Will you need them? Please don't leave unnecessary files, mark them for deletion with {{tl|delete}} template. --[[User:Derbeth|Derbeth]] [[User talk:Derbeth|talk]] 13:17, 8 March 2006 (UTC) == [[:Image:2 euro coin greece.png]] is missing a [[Wikibooks:Media#Non-free use|fair use rationale]]== {{mbox|type=warning|msg= '''Thanks for uploading [[:Image:2 euro coin greece.png]].''' The [[w:Wikimedia Foundation|Wikimedia Foundation]] is very careful about what Wikibooks includes because of [[w:United States copyright law|copyright law]], and requires that we maintain a strict [[Wikibooks:Copyright|copyright policy]]. [[:Image:2 euro coin greece.png]] and other files you uploaded may soon be deleted unless a [[Wikibooks:Media#Non-free use|rationale]] for a fair use claim is provided. In order to upload fair use material, specific rationale must be provided as to why fair use media is necessary, and how there are no free alternatives. Images or other media that do not have such rationale will likely be deleted as a copyright violation. If the information of a fair use media component could be duplicated by a free alternative, that media may not be uploaded. Please edit image descriptions pages directly to add {{tlx|fair use rationale}}; there's no need to upload the image again. If you have any questions, feel free to contact me, or [[WB:HELP|ask another Wikibookian]]. See {{UserImages2}} for a complete list of your uploads which may get deleted soon.
Thank you. [[User:MonoBot|MonoBot]] ([[User talk:MonoBot|talk]]) 04:06, 8 March 2008 (UTC)}} == Modern Greek Module == I am just writing to thank you for all the hard work you have put into the Modern Greek Wikibook. I have been trying to teach myself Greek on the internet and this wikibook is by far the best option available. Thankyou for building the book into what it now is, mainly without help. Cheers again! [[User:Storeye|Storeye]] ([[User talk:Storeye|talk]]) 11:13, 18 May 2008 (UTC) == Replacing the Recordings == I also wanted to say thanks! I am also learning modern greek. My boyfriend is Greek, and I was wondering if it would be helpful to replace the recordings with his voice? I'm sure he could find the time to do it. But I have never added anything to a wiki before, are there guidelines for how to do the reading, recording formats, etc? == Your account will be renamed ==
Hello, The developer team at Wikimedia is making some changes to how accounts work, as part of our on-going efforts to provide new and better tools for our users like cross-wiki notifications. These changes will mean you have the same account name everywhere. This will let us give you new features that will help you edit and discuss better, and allow more flexible user permissions for tools. One of the side-effects of this is that user accounts will now have to be unique across all 900 Wikimedia wikis. See [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Single User Login finalisation announcement|the announcement]] for more information. Unfortunately, your account clashes with another account also called Bcrowell. To make sure that both of you can use all Wikimedia projects in future, we have reserved the name Bcrowell~enwikibooks that only you will have. If you like it, you don't have to do anything. If you do not like it, you can [[Special:GlobalRenameRequest|pick out a different name]]. Your account will still work as before, and you will be credited for all your edits made so far, but you will have to use the new account name when you log in. Sorry for the inconvenience. Yours,
[[m:User:Keegan (WMF)|Keegan Peterzell]]
Community Liaison, Wikimedia Foundation

==The command shell== Ratpoison has a built-in "run" dialog, a quick way to launch any program without having to start a console. Type C-t ! to get a little command box from which you can launch your program. This is most useful for launching graphical applications without tying up a console, as you won't be able to see any of the output of any purely command line programs.
From the same command prompt you can invoke the ratpoison command to tweak settings and do various actions. All these commands can be looked up in the mainpage, and they are all preceded by ratpoison -c.
For example, to set the "rudeness level" to five (will be explained soon) you type ratpoison -c rudeness 5.
All these commands can of course be executed from within a console window; C-t ! is simply a more convenient variant of a command shell.
===Aliasing=== As mentioned before, ratpoison can be thought of as GNU Screen for window managing; like command line shells, it is possible to alias long commands to shorter versions.
This can be done through the extended command ability (which resembles C-t !), which is invoked via "C-t :". This opens a little box just like C-t ! does, but instead of executing shell commands, the input will be sent to ratpoison which will attempt to interpret this input as a ratpoison command; suppose one often runs Mozilla Firefox, but one grew weary of always opening a shell with C-t c and then typing in "mozilla-firefox &" (the ampersand is necessary so you can use the terminal for other things, otherwise the terminal will simply display any error or informative messages Firefox emits), or "C-t ! mozilla-firefox"?
One could decide to use a shorter name- input C-t :, and enter in "alias firefox exec mozilla-firefox", which would allow one to simply C-t: firefox, and Firefox would open up; one could even go C-t: "alias f exec mozilla-firefox" if they were rather lazy, and used no other programs beginning with the letter "f".
Aliasing is not limited to regular program names- if one drops the "exec", one could alias the command "quit" to "q": "C-t : alias q quit".
As a matter of fact, all the keyboard shortcuts one has learned for ratpoison, like C-t p, they all are actually aliases for longer commands! C-t q (which quits ratpoison) is actually an alias for C-t : quit. This is another area of borrowing from Emacs- Emacs similarly represents all keys on a keyboard and all combinations thereof, as aliases of Emacs functions.
(In these examples the command "exec" is necessary to have ratpoison evaluate the succeeding string as a shell command, and not another ratpoison command. Please see the [http://www.nongnu.org/ratpoison/doc/Other-Commands.html#index-exec-99 official documentation] on exec for more details; exec essentially does the same thing as C-t !).
{{subject|desktop environment}}

[[Category:Computer Go]]

Writing a Go GUI can have many different purposes. It can be a front-end to a Go engine so you can see the computer's play in a graphical manner; it can be an SGF viewer to allow a user to review games; it can be an SGF editor to allow users to create SGF files of their own; it can be used as part of a client application to allow users to play Go over the Internet.
This section primarily contains resources for widget libraries intended to make writing a Go GUI easier. However, when writing a Go GUI, even just a simple game viewer, there are other problems to take into account that are primarily detailed in other sections: * [[Computer Go/Writing a Go Engine|Representing the Board]] * [[Computer Go/Writing a Go Engine|Determining Legal Moves]] * [[Computer Go/Writing a Go Engine|Clearing stones]] * [[Computer Go/Writing an SGF Parser|Writing an SGF Parser]]
[[Category:Computer Go]]

==Computer Go Test Collection==
CGTC contains realistic full-board test problems taken from computer Go games.
http://www.cs.ualberta.ca/~games/go/cgtc/

GNU Go is an open-source Go-playing program that consistently achieves a rank of 8k-9k on popular Go servers. Examining how it works can be useful for those wanting to program their own Go engine.
http://www.gnu.org/software/gnugo/gnugo.html

http://computer-go.org/pipermail/computer-go/
To subscribe to the Computer-Go mailing list, visit this page:
http://computer-go.org/mailman/listinfo/computer-go

revision.text: :Hello. This is Arun T Jayapal's user page (alias deostroll). :I did my civil engineering from Govt Engineering Thrissur. I work as a night shift programmer in a call centre Allsec Technologies, Chennai. :Well, this is all that I can think to tell you more about my self. If you want to contact me use my email: ::deostroll@yahoo.com :You can also know more about me through my website: ::[http://www.geocities.com/deostroll http://www.geocities.com/deostroll]

Hi. This is Arun T Jayapal's (alias deostroll) talk page. You can leave messages here for me. It could be something like :I'd like to know your opinion on this particular subject or anything else. Use this page to basically communicate your thoughts. == Your account will be renamed ==
Hello, The developer team at Wikimedia is making some changes to how accounts work, as part of our on-going efforts to provide new and better tools for our users like cross-wiki notifications. These changes will mean you have the same account name everywhere. This will let us give you new features that will help you edit and discuss better, and allow more flexible user permissions for tools. One of the side-effects of this is that user accounts will now have to be unique across all 900 Wikimedia wikis. See [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Single User Login finalisation announcement|the announcement]] for more information. Unfortunately, your account clashes with another account also called Deostroll. To make sure that both of you can use all Wikimedia projects in future, we have reserved the name Deostroll~enwikibooks that only you will have. If you like it, you don't have to do anything. If you do not like it, you can [[Special:GlobalRenameRequest|pick out a different name]]. Your account will still work as before, and you will be credited for all your edits made so far, but you will have to use the new account name when you log in. Sorry for the inconvenience. Yours,
[[m:User:Keegan (WMF)|Keegan Peterzell]]
Community Liaison, Wikimedia Foundation
23:09, 17 March 2015 (UTC) == Renamed ==

revision.comment: /* On the definition of structural engineering */ new section
revision.text:
== About Structural Engineering ==

Structural engineering is a vast subject. It concerns other branches of engineering too. Even aeronautical degree programmes do study simple statics and bending of beams, torsion, etc.

I suppose the best way to start this module is to describe in vague what structural engineering is and what is a structural engineer's duty/responsibility. And then we can move on to basic mechanics and so on...

:--[[User:Deostroll|deostroll]] 06:58, 4 February 2006 (UTC) == About the first edit... == :I left the matter refering to concrete as such. May be it should serve other people who wish edit as a reminder about what this subject ought to describe in the future versions. Concrete is only one part of structural engineering! Meanwhile anyone is welcomed to edit this module themselves or suggest how this module should actually go about this subject. : :I would also like people to consider following questions (because even I doubt them) ::* Can a bridge be considered as a structural system? ::* Is it correct to say that strucutral engineering activites consists of analysis and design? ::* How should this article/module touch subjects like strucutral analysis and design? Shouldn't they be separate modules? --[[User:Deostroll|deostroll]] 08:31, 4 February 2006 (UTC) It would be better if you add diagrams and drawings for clearing the subjects. And do you consider clarifying what is "statically determinate structure"? == Structual analysis and design == There is no design without structural analysis. However I think they are two different subjects... I'm not sure why they have a category with both. (see structural analysis and design) == On the definition of structural engineering == The quote "Structural Engineering is the art of moulding materials we do not wholly understand into shapes we cannot precisely analyze, so as to withstand forces we cannot really assess, in such a way that the community at large has no reason to suspect the extent of our ignorance" is incorrectly attributed to James E. Amrhein. Amrhein himself has confirmed that he frequently uses the quote, but is not the original author (see January 2009 issue of STRUCTURE Magazine). This quote is a slight revision from the definition in the 1967 textbook ''Structural Analysis Volume One'' by Dr. E.H. Brown. Brown's definition was "The art of moulding materials we do not really understand into shapes we cannot really analyze, so as to withstand forces we cannot really assess, in such a way that the public does not really suspect." Mr. Amrhein is not even responsible for making the modification to its longer and less repetitive form; that credit probably belongs to Dr. A.R. Dykes (see May 1978 issue of The Structural Engineer).

page.title: Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 11 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988

revision.text:
Subsection (1) provides that a [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Residency|non-UK resident]] [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Company|company]] is only within the charge to corporation tax if it carries on a [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Trade|trade]] in the United Kingdom through a [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Permanent establishment|permanent establishment]] in the United Kingdom. This does not necessarily mean that a non-UK resident company that is not carrying on a trade in the United Kingdom through a permanent establishment is not subject to UK taxation on its profits, as it may well fall within the charge to income tax. This is typically the case for non-UK resident companies that receive income from UK land, where income less expenses is charged to income tax at the [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Basic rate|basic rate]] (22% in 2005-06). The precise meaning of "non-UK resident", "carrying on a trade" "in" (the United Kingdom) and "permanent establishment" are all important in deciding whether a foreign company is within the charge to corporation tax, and if so, to what extent.
Subsection (2) provides that a non-UK resident company within the charge to corporation tax is charged to corporation tax only on its profits, wherever arising, that are attributable to the permanent establishment.
Subsection (2A) provides a list of which profits are attributable to a permanent establishment, namely: *trading income arising directly or indirectly through or from the establishment *income from property or rights used by, or held by or for, the establishment, and; *[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Chargeable gain|chargeable gains]] failing within [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 10B of the Taxation of Chargeable Gains Act 1992|Section 10B of TCGA]] (i) by virtue of assets being used or held for the purposes of the trade carried on by the company through the establishment, or (ii) by virtue of assets being used or held for the purposes of the establishment or being acquired for use by or for the purposes of the establishment. In practice, deciding what this amounts to can be difficult, particularly in the financial services industry, where funds held overseas may be supporting business arising from a UK permanent establishment. This Subsection is therefore supplemented by [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 11AA of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 11AA]] and [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Schedule A1 to the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Schedule A1]]. Life insurance companies have their own rules set out in Sections 11A to 11C of ICTA (as deemed to be inserted by Schedule 19AC to ICTA).
Subsection (3) mimics the provision in [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 7 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 7]] that applies to UK resident companies. It provides that where a non-UK resident company to which this Section applies has received income under deduction of income tax, and it brings that income into its corporation tax computation, the income tax suffered may be used to offset the corporation tax charge for the period in which that income is brought into the corporation tax computation.
Subsection (4) disapplies subsection (3) for a payment of loan interest to which [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 369 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 369 of ICTA]] applies. Section 369 deals with mortgage relief at source. As mortgage relief at source no longer applies, this subsection no longer has any practical effect. This Subsection mimics Section 7(3). [[Category:Taxation in the United Kingdom]]

'''Company''' is defined for the purposes of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988 by [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 832 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 832 of ICTA]] as:
*any body corporate or unincorporated association but does not include a partnership, a local authority or a [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Local authority association|local authority association]]
However, this definition is subject to [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 468 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 468 of ICTA]] and does not apply to the following provisions of ICTA:
#Chapter 1 of Part XVII (Cancellation of tax advantages from certain transactions in securities) #Sections 774 to 777 #Section 839 (Connected persons) #Paragraph 15 of Schedule 3 (which has now been repealed)
Nor does it apply where the context requires otherwise because some other definition of "company" applies.
[[Category:Taxation in the United Kingdom]]

The following definitions may be relevant:
*[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Caravan|Caravan]] *[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Company|Company]] *[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Furnished lettings|Furnished lettings]] *[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Houseboat|Houseboat]] *[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Profession|Profession]] *[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Profits|Profits]] *[[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definition/Qualifying distribution|Qualifying distribution]]
[[Category:Taxation in the United Kingdom]]

page.title: Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 14 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988

revision.text:
Section 14 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988 defines '''qualifying distribution''' for the purposes of ICTA. The definition is as follows:
:any [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Corporation tax/Definitions/distribution|distribution]] other than -
:(a) a distribution which, in relation to the [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Company|company]] making it, is a distribution only by virtue of [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 209 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 209(2)(c) of ICTA]]; or
:(b) a distribution consisting of any share capital or security which the company making the distribution has directly or indirectly received from the company by which the share capital or security was issued and which, in realtion to the latter company, is a distribution by virtue only of section 209(2)(c).
Section 14 used also to include information about advance corporation tax, which was abolished in 1998.
[[Category:Taxation in the United Kingdom]]

page.title: Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definition/Qualifying distribution

redirect.title: Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 14 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988

page.title: Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 15 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988

revision.comment: Reverted edit of [[Special:Contributions/Skipper|Skipper]], changed back to last version by Jguk
revision.text:
This Section sets out Schedule A, the charge to tax arising from income on UK land. ==The charge to tax== Subsection (1) sets out the four paragraphs of the charge. Paragraph 1 raises the charge on "the annual profits arising from a business carried on for exploitation, as a source of rents of other receipts, of any estate, interest or rights in or over land in the United Kingdom. To the extent a transaction is entered into for such exploitation it is treated as being entered into in the course of such a business. All such property businesses and transactions by a person are treated as if it is one business being carried on. There are two exceptions for this: first in respect of non-resident companies (see Subsection (1A)) below; second in respect of life [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Insurance company|insurance companies]], where there is a separate rule in [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 432AA of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Sections 432AA]] and [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 441B of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|441B(2A)]] of ICTA.
Paragraph 2 carves out certain items from the charge to Schedule A: *Profits arising from the occupation of land; *Profits charged to tax under Case I of [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 18 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Schedule D]] under [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 53 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 53(1) of ICTA]] (farming and marketing gardening) or [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 55 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 55 of ICTA]] (mines, quarries and other concerns); *Receipts or expenses taken into account in the taxation of tied premises (under [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 98 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1998|Section 98 of ICTA]]); *Rent taxed under [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 18 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Schedule D]] under [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 119 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 119 of ICTA]] (rent, etc. payable in connection with mines, quarries and other concerns) or under [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 120 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Section 120(1) of ICTA]] (certain rent, etc. payable in respect of electric line wayleaves); *Credits and debits arising from [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/loan relationships|loan relationships]] or [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/derivative contracts|derivative contracts]].
Paragraph 3 deems rights in static [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Caravan|caravans]] and [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Houseboat|houseboats]] to be rights in UK land for the purposes of Schedule A.
Paragraph 4 brings income receipts or other consideration received from the provision of furniture in [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Furnished lettings|furnished lettings]] into Schedule A, unless the receipts are charged under Case I of [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Legislation/Section 18 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988|Schedule D]] as receipts of a furniture letting trade. ==Other Subsections== Subsection (1A) provides that for [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Residency|non-UK resident]] [[Taxation in the United Kingdom/Definitions/Company|companies]], businesses carried on and transactions entered into by it, the profits on which are within the corporation tax charge, are charged to corporation tax under Schedule A. However, a UK property business that falls to be within the charge to income tax is charged to income tax under Chapter 3 of Part 3 of ITTOIA. If a non-resident company has some property business within the charge to corporation tax, and some within the charge to income tax, it is treated as though it has two separate property businesses.
Subsection (3A) provides that Subsection (1) applies for corporation tax purposes, but not for income tax purposes (except insofar as it is necessary for them to apply for income tax purposes to ensure the application of Subsection (1) for corporation tax purposes.
Subsection (4) Notes that Part II of ICTA contains more information on the charge to Schedule A for corporation tax purposes, and that Part II of ICTA also contains more information on the income tax charge to profits on a property business under Chapter 3 of Part 3 of ITTOIA (which doesn't apply to entities within the charge to corporation tax). [[Category:Taxation in the United Kingdom]]
